item.description: #Antibiotics [[Cell wall inhibitors]] [[Protein synthesis inhibitors]]
#Antibiotics #Cell-wall-inhibitors [[β-lactam antibiotics]]

#Antibiotics #Cell-wall-inhibitors #β-lactam-antibiotics Classification [[Penicillins]] [[Cephalosporins]] [[Carbapenems]] [[Monobactams]] Structure They contain a β-lactam ring. Pharmacokinetics Mechanism of action They inhibit the synthesis of the bacterial peptidoglycan wall, specially in gram-positive bacteria.

They act on [[Streptococci]], but resistant [[Viridans Streptococci]] and [[Streptococcus pneumoniae]] are emerging, specially in pediatric patients; most commonly, they are also resistant to third-generation [[Cephalosporins]].

#Antibiotics #Cell-wall-inhibitors #β-lactam-antibiotics Antimicrobial activity Penicillin G (benzylpenicillin) and penicillin V (phenoxymethyl) act on aerobic gram-positive organisms, but penicillin G is 5 to 10 times more active against [[Neisseria]] and other anaerobes such as [[Clostridium]].

#Antibiotics #Cell-wall-inhibitors #β-lactam-antibiotics Classification Penicillins are classified according to their spectra of activity: [[Penicillin G and penicillin V]] [[Penicillinase-resistant penicillins]] [[Aminopenicillins]] [[Antipseudomonal penicillins]]
#Antidepressants [[Selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors]] [[Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors]] [[Tricyclic antidepressants]]
#Antidepressants #SNRI Examples [[Duloxetine]]

#Antidepressants #SNRI Mechanism of action Inhibition of the serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake at the spinal level results in enhanced sphincter contraction. Therapeutic indications [[Daytime urinary incontinence]] Sources Amboss: Stress Incontinence
#Antidepressants #Tricyclic-antidepressants List [[Imipramine]]
#Antidepressants #Tricyclic-antidepressants #Antimuscarinics Therapeutic indications [[Daytime urinary incontinence]]
#Autonomic-modulators [[Cholinergic antagonists]] [[Cholinergic agonists]] [[α-adrenergic agonists]] [[α-adrenergic antagonists]] [[β-adrenergic agonists]]
#Autonomic-modulators #Cholinergic-antagonists #Antimuscarinics Therapeutic indications [[Daytime urinary incontinence]] Adults 5 mg two or three times a day Max: 20 mg / day

#Autonomic-modulators #Cholinergic-antagonists #Antimuscarinics Therapeutic indications [[Daytime urinary incontinence]] Adults 15 mg two or three times a day Increase to four times a day if required Max: 60 mg / day

#Autonomic-modulators #Cholinergic-antagonists #Antimuscarinics Mechanism of action They inhibit M3 receptors on the detrusor muscle, inhibiting its contraction with acetylcholine. Adverse effects Flushing Accommodation problems Tachycardia Hyperactivity Dry mouth Residual urine Constipation Blurred vision Impaired cognition Glaucoma Examples [[Propiverine]] [[Oxybutynin]] [[Darifenacin]] (selective) [[Solifenacin]] (selective) [[Tolterodine]] [[Fesoterodine]] [[Trospium]] [[Scopolamine]] [[Flavoxate]]
#Autonomic-modulators #Cholinergic-agonists [[Muscarinic agonists]]
#Autonomic-modulators #Cholinergic-agonists #Muscarinic-agonists Examples [[Bethanechol]]

#Autonomic-modulators #Cholinergic-agonists #Muscarinic-agonists Mechanism of action It acts on M3 receptors, causing contraction of the detrusor muscle. Therapeutic indications [[Daytime urinary incontinence]] Sources Amboss
#Autonomic-modulators #Cholinergic-antagonists [[Muscarinic antagonists]] [[Nicotinic antagonists]]
#Autonomic-modulators #α-antagonists [[α1-adrenergic antagonists]]

#Autonomic-modulators #α-antagonists Mechanism of action They inhibit adrenergic receptors in the internal urethral sphincter and the prostate, producing relaxation of the bladder neck and prostate and reducing obstruction of urinary outflow.
#Autonomic-modulators #β-agonists [[β3-adrenergic agonists]]

#Autonomic-modulators #β-agonists Mechanism of action These drugs cause direct relaxation of the detrusor muscle, inhibiting spontaneous contractile activity in the bladder and reducing in its afferent activity.
#Autonomic-modulators #β-agonists Therapeutic indications [[Daytime urinary incontinence]] Adults 25-100 mg / day
#Steroids Examples [[Estrogen]]
#Steroids Mechanism of action Topical estrogen increases urethral blood flow and sensitivity of α-adrenergic receptors. Therapeutic indications [[Daytime urinary incontinence]]
